thread.title: Peterson: Changing coaches won't suddenly liven up ISU offense
thread.title_full: Peterson: Changing coaches won't suddenly liven up ISU offense

title: Peterson: Changing coaches won't suddenly liven up ISU offense
text:
Peterson: Changing coaches won't suddenly liven up ISU offense Randy Peterson looks ahead to the Cyclones' contest against No. 3 TCU Post to Facebook Peterson: Changing coaches won't suddenly liven up ISU offense Randy Peterson looks ahead to the Cyclones' contest against No. 3 TCU Check out this story on desmoinesregister.com: http://dmreg.co/1LpOwhL Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 3 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Peterson: Changing coaches won't suddenly liven up ISU offense Randy Peterson , rpeterson@dmreg.com 6:07 p.m. CDT October 11, 2015 Texas Tech's Jakeem Grant is tackled by Iowa State's Nigel Tribune during an NCAA college football game, Saturday, Oct. 10, 2015, in Lubbock, Texas. Mark Rogers/AP Iowa State's Quenton Bundrage hauls in a pass during an NCAA college football game against Texas Tech, Saturday, Oct. 10, 2015, in Lubbock, Texas. Mark Rogers/AP Texas Tech's DeAndre Washington carries the ball as Iowa State's Jarnor Jones defends during an NCAA college football game, Saturday, Oct. 10, 2015, in Lubbock, Texas. Mark Rogers/AP Iowa State's Allen Lazard makes a catch while defended by Texas Tech's Nigel Bethel II during an NCAA college football game, Saturday, Oct. 10, 2015, in Lubbock, Texas. Mark Rogers/AP Texas Tech's Tevin Madison intercepts a pass intended for Iowa State's D'Vario Montgomery during an NCAA college football game, Saturday, Oct. 10, 2015, in Lubbock, Texas. Mark Rogers/AP Texas Tech's Jakeem Grant (11) carries the ball as teammate DeAndre Washington (21) blocks Iowa State's Jordan Harris during an NCAA college football game, Saturday, Oct. 10, 2015, in Lubbock, Texas. Mark Rogers/AP Texas Tech's Branden Jackson carries the ball while defended by Iowa State's Qujuan Floyd (7) during an NCAA college football game, Saturday, Oct. 10, 2015, in Lubbock, Texas. Mark Rogers/AP Iowa State Cyclones quarterback Sam Richardson (12) drops back to pass against the Texas Tech Red Raiders in the first half at Jones AT&T Stadium. Michael C. Johnson/USA TODAY Sports Iowa State Cyclones quarterback Sam Richardson (12) hands the ball off to running back Mike Warren (2) in the game against the Texas Tech Red Raiders at Jones AT&T Stadium. Michael C. Johnson/USA TODAY Sports Iowa State Cyclones wide receiver Quentin Bundrage (9) rushes against Texas Tech Red Raiders defensive back Dakota Allen (4) in the first half at Jones AT&T Stadium. Michael C. Johnson/USA TODAY Sports Iowa State Cyclones quarterback Sam Richardson (12) rushes against Texas Tech Red Raiders defensive lineman Branden Jackson (9) in the first half at Jones AT&T Stadium. Michael C. Johnson/USA TODAY Sports Iowa State Cyclones running back Mike Warren (2) rushes against the Texas Tech Red Raiders in the first half at Jones AT&T Stadium. Michael C. Johnson/USA TODAY Sports Iowa State Cyclones head coach Paul Rhoads on the sidelines during the game with the Texas Tech Red Raiders at Jones AT&T Stadium. Michael C. Johnson/USA TODAY Sports Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Allen Lazard fights for yardage during Saturday's game against Texas Tech. (Photo: John Weast/Getty Images) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 3 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
LUBBOCK, Texas — And you probably thought Texas and Kansas State were the remaining games Iowa State legitimately had a chance to win. 
Think again. 
If the Cyclones play against them the way they played in Saturday’s 66-31 blowout loss at Texas Tech, then it’s going to be another two-win season — and possibly an interesting offseason of wondering if there’s a coach anywhere capable of turning around this program that has just four wins over the last 17 games. 
Mike Warren and Allen Lazard can’t carry this 2-3 outfit that faces third-ranked TCU at 6 p.m. Saturday by themselves. They’re good. They’re very good. They’re not Trevone Boykin good. 
Iowa State needs immediate change, and I’m not referring to a mid-season replacement of the head coach right now. If athletics director Jamie Pollard was going to do that, presumably he’d have done it during the off week. 
Beyond fans calling for coaches immediately to be canned and starters to be replaced, there’s a lot of work to be done inside the football complex for the Cyclones to even be respectable on Saturday. Like what happened to the tight ends? And how about a few tosses down field where speedy receivers can do their stuff? 
Texas Tech did it. Others do it, too. It's time Iowa State joins in on this fun. Nothing else seems to be working in that aspect of the offense. 
What happened to the passing game? 
This Sam Richardson-led passing attack hasn’t even come close to living up to expectations. 
Veteran receivers, a veteran quarterback, and experienced offensive linemen have not translated to what everyone thought it would. Nothing is going to change, however, from a personnel standpoint. 
Coach Paul Rhoads said after Saturday’s game that Richardson will continue to start. He’s not confident just yet using Joel Lanning in an extended passing role, and Grant Rohach hasn’t even played this season. 
“(Lanning) hasn’t had a chance to really go out there and run the offense,” Rhoads said. 
So it’s all-Sam — until Lanning becomes comfortable running the team. Peterson: Save for Warren, nothing works for Cyclones 
Mike Warren’s next step is ... 
“I don’t know. I don’t really know,” the redshirt freshman said after rushing for 245 yards on 23 carries Saturday. “I guess you can just keep going up from here.” 
Iowa State rushed for 315 yards against the Big 12’s worst rush defense Saturday, the most for the Cyclones in a game since getting 368 against the Red Raiders in 2011. 
TCU, Saturday’s opponent, is giving up 183.0 rushing yards a game, so it could be another big one for Warren. 
“I feel like this game truly showed that we can run the ball,” said Warren, who needs to average 60.9 rushing yards a game over the remainder of the season to become Iowa State’s first 1,000-yard rusher since Alexander Robinson’s 1,195 in 2009. 
They better run it well, because Iowa State is getting nothing from the other piece of the offense. And speaking of Allen Lazard highlight-reel catches ... 
He needs more touches. Just saying. Mike Warren delivers another historic ISU performance 
It’s everyone, including the place-kicker 
Rhoads probably was just messing with Cole Netten’s mind, trying to motivate his once-solid place-kicker by saying that role is now open to anyone who has a good week of practice. 
But you heard it here first — Netten isn’t losing his job. 
As inconsistent as he has been throughout this 2-3 season, Netten still is the best on Iowa State’s campus, and anyhow, Rhoads wasn’t exactly enamored by replacement Chris Francis’ PAT effort late in Saturday’s game. 
“It was an awful kick, by the way,” Rhoads said. ISU status report: Struggles key Red Raiders rout 
Here come the Big 12 favorites 
If Texas Tech was the (alleged) easiest among Iowa State’s run of games against three of the nation’s top offenses, then what can be in store when TCU comes to town? 
Here’s a hint: Cover your eyes, if you’re a Cyclones fan. 
“On paper, the next two offenses are better than this one,” Rhoads said after the Red Raiders amassed a school-record 776 yards Saturday. 
The Horned Frogs are 6-0 record after rallying late to beat Kansas State 52-45 on Saturday. The Cyclones don’t stand much of a chance of winning this game, anyway, but there’s no chance without fixing everything that went wrong Saturday. 
“We have to play better perimeter run and pass defense,” Rhoads said. “That’s our outside linebackers, cornerbacks and safeties. Those are the guys on alert when those plays occur. 
“We have to get off blocks better, and we have to tackle with urgency and immediacy. The speed and pace isn’t going to slow down the next two weeks.” 
Cyclone sports columnist Randy Peterson has been reporting on ISU during the past five decades. Follow @RandyPete. CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 3 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://dmreg.co/1LpOwhL TOP VIDEOS
